bio: Sanjay Singh is a Staff Software Engineer at LinkedIn with over a decade of experience designing and scaling infrastructure and security systems. He has led large-scale initiatives in Zero Trust architecture, Kubernetes platforms, and traffic infrastructure, focusing on practical, open source solutions for enterprise environments. Sanjay’s work emphasizes bridging security with usability, enabling organizations to adopt advanced security postures without disrupting developer productivity. He has authored papers on adaptive access control and is passionate about building resilient, vendor-neutral systems that address real-world security challenges at scale.

bio: Pam Lindemoen is the Chief Security Officer and Vice President of Strategy at the Retail & Hospitality Information Sharing and Analysis Center (RH-ISAC). With nearly 30 years of experience, she oversees security operations, strategic planning, and partner engagement. Her background includes roles as CISO Advisor at Cisco and Deputy CISO at Anthem, where she developed risk management programs and responded to a major cyberattack.

bio: Brian has spent more than 20 years at the intersection of law, public policy, and technology. He served six years as a Managing Director at EY-Parthenon, leading a 50+ person team focused on cybersecurity, data privacy, and responsible AI in transactional contexts, and led 500+ security and privacy assessments. Previously, Brian spent seven years as a U.S. DOJ cybercrime prosecutor, including as National Coordinator for 300 cybercrime prosecutors, and served as an Assistant Attorney General in New York. He also practiced technology and IP litigation at Morrison & Foerster and Paul Weiss. Brian is the co-founder of FormerGov.com, a directory connecting organizations with former government and military professionals.

bio: Rebecca Grapsy is a communications professional with more than a decade of experience bridging communications, policy, and technical domains. At the Department of Transportation, she translated complex regulatory and safety issues into clear, high-impact narratives for industry, media, and the public before moving into the automotive industry earlier this year. She specializes in building productive cross-functional relationships with technical teams, including the engineers she worked with at the Naval Surface Warfare Center – Carderock as well as those at NHTSA and USDOT. She holds an undergraduate degree in Communications and a Master’s degree in Homeland Security from Penn State.

She holds an undergraduate degree in Communications and a Master’s degree in Homeland Security from Penn State.

bio: Mitch Ashley is VP Practice Lead, Analyst at Futurum Group, leading Software Lifecycle Engineering. With 30+ years as entrepreneur, CTO, CIO, and engineering leader, he brings production experience architecting and operating systems at scale across cybersecurity, PKI, and SaaS. His practice analyzes how AI transforms software development. 2026 theme: developers no longer write code but engineer how AI agents build software. Coverage spans AI-native development, DevOps, DevSecOps, security, observability, and platform engineering. Mitch founded Techstrong Research, proving practitioner-informed analysis drives client engagement. At Futurum, he executes this model at platform scale with timely, independent analysis grounded in operational reality.

bio: Dominik Swierad is Senior Product Manager in the cybersecurity space at Google, involved in both Sec-Gemini and applied AI within detection and response. His focus is on leveraging AI and agent technology to help security teams stay ahead in a rapidly changing threat environment. Prior to Google, he worked in the telecommunications industry on global connectivity solutions and infrastructure.

bio: Caroline Tsay is a Board Member and CEO with deep experience scaling enterprise software and consumer internet businesses. She serves on the boards of The Coca-Cola Company, Morningstar, Semrush, and NiCE, and advises venture-backed startups on AI adoption, product strategy, and go-to-market execution. She was Co-Founder and CEO of Compute Software, an agentic AI cloud optimization company. Previously, she was VP and GM of Software at HP Enterprise and led product for Yahoo! Search, AI, and E-Commerce. She began her career at IBM Global Services and has been recognized as one of WomenInc.'s 2025 Most Influential Women Corporate Board Directors, National Diversity Council's Top 50 Most Powerful Women in Technology, and Silicon Valley Business Journal’s 40 Under 40.
companyName: The Coca-Cola Company, Morningstar, Semrush, NiCE

bio: Abhilasha Bhargav-Spantzel is a Partner Security Architect at Microsoft, focusing on AI and foundational security. Previously, she spent 14 years at Intel driving hardware-based security and identity product architecture. She earned her PhD from Purdue University, specializing in identity and privacy protection through cryptography and biometrics. A recognized thought leader, Abhilasha shapes the future of cybersecurity through innovation and education. She is a sought-after speaker delivering Keynotes at leading conferences. Her contributions include five book chapters, 30+ ACM/IEEE publications, and 40+ patents. Passionate about diversity and inclusion, she champions STEM cybersecurity education for K–12 students.

A recognized thought leader, Abhilasha shapes the future of cybersecurity through innovation and education. She is a sought-after speaker delivering Keynotes at leading conferences. bio: Cameron Ramage is Senior Legal Counsel at Cirrus Logic, Inc., headquartered in Austin, Texas. Based in Cirrus Logic’s Edinburgh, UK office, Cameron advises on the intersection of artificial intelligence, compliance, and data privacy, collaborating with Information Security colleagues on risk management and enabling strategic AI adoption. Cameron also advises on a broad range of other legal and regulatory matters across the UK, US, and Asia-Pacific regions, including intellectual property and software licensing, corporate governance, and employment matters. In 2024, Cameron won the Law Society of Scotland’s In-House Rising Star Award.

bio: Jennifer S. Burnside, CISSP, is a Practice Leader for Crisis Communications at Mandiant. Jennifer has over 25 years crisis response and strategic communications experience, including as the FBI's Senior Executive over Strategic Communications. She has led operational, intelligence, and community engagement teams, serving in several divisions including Cyber, Counterterrorism, Counterintelligence, and International Operations. She was detailed as the FBI's Senior Liaison Officer to the Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency. An experienced incident manager and planner, she specializes in helping clients and their boards evaluate, prepare, and manage operational and reputational risks through developing, refining, and testing communication strategies, plans, and playbooks.

bio: Jim Shreve advises all types of companies on the myriad legal concerns surrounding confidential information and how such information is stored and transmitted. Applying the law to rapidly changing technology and software capabilities, he provides clients with a profile of their potential risk, then works closely with executive leadership, legal, IT, and compliance Information Security teams to develop a comprehensive and practical plan for risk avoidance and responding to cyber and data issues. Jim helps clients develop robust and responsive security, privacy policies, and governance documents, meet applicable data safeguarding requirements, and implement compliance programs.

bio: Diana Freed is an Assistant Professor of Computer and Data Science at Brown University, a Visiting Scholar at Harvard Law School’s Petrie-Flom Center, and a Faculty Associate at the Berkman Klein Center for Internet and Society at Harvard. She is also a 2025–2026 CRA and Microsoft AI Trustworthy Research Fellow. Her interdisciplinary research focuses on computer security, privacy, AI governance, and digital health, with a particular emphasis on technology’s role in supporting vulnerable populations. She serves on the advisory board of the World Childhood Foundation and is a Member of the New England Public Interest Technology Leadership Committee. Her work has been recognized globally with awards at top-tier conferences.

bio: Kristie Chon Flynn is passionate about helping companies harness data to drive innovation grounded in digital responsibility. At Google, she leads a global team architecting scalable data risk products and serves as Data Protection Officer, transforming complex regulatory hurdles into strategic opportunities. She actively engages externally to foster industry-wide trust and serves as a Board Director for five Google Korean entities. Kristie brings deep expertise in scaling global programs (0-100) from her prior roles as Chief Privacy Officer at PayPal and HCL Technologies, and at American Express. Her career is defined by transforming how organizations approach data risk to build products that drive brand loyalty and customer experience.

bio:
Kobi, a serial entrepreneur with 30+ years of experience in technology and investment fields, co-founded Glilot Capital in 2011 with Arik Kleinstein. Kobi’s vision for Glilot was to create a leading investment platform that will grow Israel’s finest innovating companies. Kobi’s vast experience in building businesses continuously contributes to Glilot's portfolio. His success-driven execution has resulted in 23 exits to date and a strong portfolio. Prior to founding Glilot, he founded and successfully exited several technology companies including Lamda Communication Networks (acquired by NICE Systems) and iWeb Technologies
(acquired by a Japanese consortium). He was also a founding team member of Infogear Technologies, the creator of the original iPhone (acquired by Cisco).

bio: Brian Krebs is an independent investigative reporter and author of KrebsOnSecurity.com, an award-winning cybersecurity news site that celebrated its 16th year in December 2025. From 1996-2009, Krebs was a reporter for The Washington Post and Washingtonpost.com, where he authored the popular Security Fix blog. His current reporting focuses primarily on exposing complex, distributed cybercrime operations, and identifying the people and entities that support them. In 2015, the National Press Foundation presented Krebs with its Chairman's Citation, which honors individuals or organizations whose work falls outside traditional categories of excellence.  Krebs graduated in 1994 from George Mason University with a B.A. in International Relations.

bio: Mark Cherp is a research group manager at CyberArk, specializing in adversarial AI, offensive low-level research, and automated bug discovery, with a strong passion for fuzzing. He has previously worked at Microsoft, Check Point, and other leading companies in the Israeli cyber industry. Throughout his career, Mark has explored multiple domains of vulnerability research, including AI, cloud, network, mobile, and endpoint security. When not immersed in security research, he enjoys rock climbing, where problem-solving takes a more vertical form.

bio: Ross Haleliuk is a Co-Founder and CEO of a Stealth-mode cybersecurity startup, cybersecurity operator, and a product leader. Outside of work, Ross is a startup advisor, angel investor, and a frequent contributor to leading tech media such as TechCrunch, Forbes, VentureBeat, and Dark Reading. Ross is an author of "Venture in Security," an award-winning blog with over 750,000 annual readers, widely regarded as the number one independent source about the business side of cybersecurity. His book, "Cyber for Builders: The Essential Guide to Building a Cybersecurity Startup," became an instant Amazon best seller and is recognized as a critical read for aspiring and early-stage security entrepreneurs and experienced founders alike.

Ross is an author of "Venture in Security," an award-winning blog with over 750,000 annual readers, widely regarded as the number one independent source about the business side of cybersecurity. His book, "Cyber for Builders: The Essential Guide to Building a Cybersecurity Startup," became an instant Amazon best seller and is recognized as a critical read for aspiring and early-stage security entrepreneurs and experienced founders alike.

bio: Dr. Daniel Takabi is the Director of School of Cybersecurity, Professor, and Batten Endowed Chair in Cybersecurity at Old dominion University (ODU). He has been doing research at the intersection of AI and cybersecurity for over a decade, has deep expertise in LLMs, AI security, adversarial machine learning, and autonomous agent systems. He has published over 100 papers in peer reviewed conferences and journals. His research has been supported by NSF, DoD, NSA, and Microsoft Fellowship with over $20M in funding. His team has investigated LLMs security, including the development of tools for multi-turn jailbreak analysis, backdoor attacks, and MCP security. His team also organizes a national AI security competition including AI red-teaming competition focused on attacks against LLMs.

bio: Michael Lewis is one of the most respected minds of our time and the prolific best selling  author of titles including Moneyball, The Big Short, and The Blind Side . Renowned for seeing what others miss, he shifts perspectives and broadens understanding with every conversation. His character-driven narrative nonfiction finds the fascinating in the mundane, revealing sage truths about American culture and broader humanity.  Fueled by a wandering curiosity and the unparalleled ability to make anything interesting, Michael has written more than 20 books with numerous #1 New York Times bestsellers among them. Following his interests from sports to finance to the intricacies of the human condition, his books capture and influence culture for decades beyond their publish date.

bio: Miroslav Kral is the Senior Director of Global Security Strategy at ADP (a global provider of HCM solutions). He is responsible for development and implementation of a security strategy that aligns with strategic objectives, regulations, and risk appetite of ADP. Prior to joining ADP, Miroslav spent 15 years in consulting industry partnering with complex global organizations to develop, transform, and enhance resilient cybersecurity programs.

bio: Tom has an extensive background in industrial controls and enjoys getting into the field and making things work. He has held various roles, focused on the operation, engineering, and security of industrial control systems. He started his career in the US Air Force, retiring with a total of 24 years between Active Duty, Reserves and Air Guard, and spent the last half of his service on a National Mission Team in a Cyber Operations Squadron. In addition to GRIMM, Tom is the Co-Founder of ICS Village, a non-profit educational organization that equips industry and policymakers to better defend industrial equipment through experiential awareness, education, and training. Tom calls Lehigh Valley, PA home with his six kids. In his spare time, he enjoys outdoor activities and riding motorcycles.

bio: Libertad Castro is a cybersecurity, privacy, and risk management specialist with over ten years of experience designing and leading Information Security and technology governance programs across energy, infrastructure, and technology sectors, in both public and private organizations. She is a former CISO at Iberdrola Mexico and previously served as Privacy Manager at FICO. She holds a Master’s degree in ICT Law and has hands-on experience with frameworks such as ISO standards, TOGAF, and ISC2. She is the Founder of Libertad & Co., a boutique consultancy focused on ethical, strategic, and human-centered approaches to security and privacy. Since 2017, she has been a Professor at Tecnológico de Monterrey, where she focuses on governance, and trust based organizational resilience.

bio: Taesoo Kim is a Professor in the School of Cybersecurity and Privacy (SCP) and the School of Computer Science (SCS) at Georgia ​Tech, as well as Vice President at Microsoft. Taesoo leads Team Atlanta, which won first place in the DARPA ​AI Cyber Challenge (AIxCC), a competition to build autonomous cyber reasoning systems that detect and remediate software vulnerabilities ​in open source projects, earning a total award of $6 million prize. ​He is the recipient of numerous honors, including the NSF CAREER Award (2018), the Internet Defense Prize (2015), and several best paper/artifact awards at premier venues such as SOSP’21, USENIXSecurity’18, and EuroSys’17. Taesoo holds a BS from KAIST (2009), an SM (2011), and PhD (2014) from MIT.​

Taesoo holds a BS from KAIST (2009), an SM (2011), and PhD (2014) from MIT.​

bio: Ali Ghodsi is the President, CEO and co-founder of Databricks. Under Ali’s leadership, Databricks has pioneered the data intelligence platform built on a lakehouse architecture to simplify and scale analytics and AI for thousands of global organizations. His experience as a data and AI leader spans more than 20 years, with deep roots in AI research and open source software. He was one of the creators of open source project, Apache Spark. In addition to his role at Databricks, he is an adjunct professor at the University of California, Berkeley, where he focuses on research in the areas of computer systems and AI, and is on the board of UC Berkeley’s RiseLab. Originally from Iran and Sweden, Ali resides in Berkeley, CA with his family.

bio: Byron Boots is a Senior Security Assurance Automation Engineer and was the lead on developing the functionality for the GRC tool built internally. He has extensive GRC experience and after working in the space for many years, returned to school and obtained a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science to shift to being a GRC Engineer full time. He has a deep understanding of compliance and risk needs, having worked in both external and internal roles, and his unique experience set allows him to deeply understand use cases and translate business requirements from non-technical stakeholders into technical requirements that engineers can leverage and work to implement.

bio: Jason Clinton is Deputy Chief Information Security Officer and was the first CISO at Anthropic. Previously, he led Chrome Infrastructure Security at Google. Earlier work includes ChromeOS build integrity, Android Pay security, digital coupons, beowulf computing, and secure thin clients. He's the Author of "Ruby Phrasebook" and contributed to the GNOME project.

bio: Dr. Ang Cui is the Founder and Chief Scientist of Red Balloon Security, a leading cybersecurity provider and research firm that specializes in the protection of embedded devices across all industries. Ang received his PhD in Computer Science from Columbia University in 2015 and was part of the Intrusion Detection Systems Lab. His doctoral dissertation, titled “Embedded System Security: A Software-based Approach,” focused exclusively on scientific inquiries concerning the exploitation and defense of embedded systems. Ang is the Creator of Firmware Reverse Analysis Konsole (FRAK) and the Inventor of Software Symbiote technology, both of which enable pioneering firmware analysis and defense for embedded devices.

His doctoral dissertation, titled “Embedded System Security: A Software-based Approach,” focused exclusively on scientific inquiries concerning the exploitation and defense of embedded systems. Ang is the Creator of Firmware Reverse Analysis Konsole (FRAK) and the Inventor of Software Symbiote technology, both of which enable pioneering firmware analysis and defense for embedded devices.

bio: Tamir Yehuda is a Senior Security Researcher and cloud security team lead at Varonis. He is a full-stack hacker with experience in malware analysis, Windows & AD domains, SaaS applications, and cloud infrastructure. Tamir specialize in IaaS & PaaS research focusing mainly on Azure, GCP, AWS, Salesforce, and ServiceNow. He brings over eight years of experience in various types of security research and red teaming.

bio: Eric Huber leads the Cybercrime Research team for TD Bank. He is passionate about leveraging his unique blend of fraud, cybersecurity, and payment systems knowledge to educate and protect individuals and organizations. He has extensive experience building and leading high-performing teams that excel in researching, investigating, and preventing a wide variety of cybercrime and payment fraud incidents. He has built and led cybercrime teams at organizations such as JP Morgan Chase, Honeywell International, and the National White Collar Crime Center (NW3C). He holds a variety of degrees and certifications including an MBA from the University of Florida. He is the curator of The Fraudster Glossary at www.fraudsterglossary.com.

bio: Greg Clark is a seasoned leader in Secure Information Management with 20+ years across product management and product marketing. He has led portfolios at OpenText, CA, Autonomy, HP/HPE, Micro Focus, and OpenText Cybersecurity spanning data security, ECM, archiving, compliance, and eDiscovery. Formerly head of Data Security PM at OpenText Cybersecurity, he launched the global data security SaaS platform and advanced sovereign cloud initiatives, delivering privacy-preserving, insight-driven products. Greg is now Senior Director of Product Management for OpenText Cybersecurity, driving the integrated roadmap across Threat Detection & Response, Data Security, IAM, and Application Security, with a focus on cross-domain integration and the responsible use of GenAI and agentic AI.

bio: Sami Ruohonen works at Ericsson conducting threat research and building threat detection systems in 5G and 4G mobile networks, with focus in EDR and SIEM threat detection capabilities in Core and RAN. With over ten years of experience in the cybersecurity field, he has worked in threat intelligence conducting technical threat research, in incident response investigating APT cyberattacks, and built EDR systems for IT and Telecom networks.

bio: Erez Liebermann is a Partner at Debevoise & Plimpton's Data Strategy & Security Group. His practice focuses on advising major businesses, senior executives, and boards on a wide range of complex, high-impact cyber incident response matters and on data-related regulatory requirements and inquiries. Erez previously led major cyber investigations for 10 years at the Department of Justice as Chief of the Computer Hacking and IP Section of the US Attorney's Office. He then served as Chief Counsel of Cybersecurity & Privacy at Prudential Financial. Erez combines his technical training as an aerospace engineer with his experience in government and in-house to distill technical issues for executives and regulators and devise strategies for effective crisis resolution.

bio: Daniel Rohrer has held a variety of technical and leadership roles in his 24 years at NVIDIA. Daniel has taken his integrated knowledge of "everything NVIDIA" to hone security practices through the delivery of advanced technical solutions, reliable processes, and strategic investments to build trustworthy security solutions. He has a Master’s Degree in Computer Science from the University of North Carolina.

bio: Cynthia Dwork, Gordon McKay Professor of Computer Science at Harvard, is known for inventing differential privacy, non-malleable cryptography, and proofs of work; for launching the theory of algorithmic fairness; and for seminal contributions in lattice-based cryptography, distributed computing, and validity in adaptive/exploratory data analysis.  Her honors include the US National Medal of Science, the Hamming Medal, and the Dijkstra, Gödel, Knuth, and Kanellakis Awards, and the RSA Award for Excellence in Mathematics. She is a member of the US National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and of the American Philosophical Society.
globalBio: Cynthia Dwork, Gordon McKay Professor of Computer Science at Harvard, is known for inventing differential privacy, non-malleable cryptography, and proofs of work; for launching the theory of algorithmic fairness; and for seminal contributions in lattice-based cryptography, distributed computing, and validity in adaptive/exploratory data analysis.  Her honors include the US National Medal of Science, the Hamming Medal, and the Dijkstra, Gödel, Knuth, and Kanellakis Awards, and the RSA Award for Excellence in Mathematics. She is a member of the US National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Engineering and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and of the American Philosophical Society.

bio: Mohammad Islam is a Distinguished Engineer on Uber’s Security team, where he builds scalable systems that secure data and access across Uber’s global platform. He has deep expertise in distributed systems, security, big data infrastructure, and machine learning. Previously, he worked at LinkedIn on the Hadoop development team and at Yahoo! as an Architect and Technical Lead for Apache Oozie. He Co-Authored the O’Reilly book "Apache Oozie" and served as VP and PMC Chair of Apache Oozie. He is also a PMC Member for Apache TEZ, with contributions to Apache YARN/MapReduce and Hive. Mohammad holds a PhD in Computer Science from Ohio State University.

Mohammad holds a PhD in Computer Science from Ohio State University.

bio: Abu Shohel Ahmed is a security researcher and currently working as a Security Product Manager at Ericsson. His research interests include threat detection, protocol analysis, and building secure systems. Previously, he has worked on developing security solutions focusing on eSIM, PKI, and telco XDRs. He is credited with multiple CVEs, speaking at Blackhat, and publishing in high impact security journals. He enjoys communicating technical details in blog posts, publications, and onstage. He holds a PhD degree in Computer Security.

bio: Principal Analyst, John Grady, covers network security at Enterprise Strategy Group. John leverages nearly 20 years of IT vendor and analyst experience to help clients identify and quantify key market trends to facilitate data-driven business decisions. Prior to ESG, John spent four years at Symantec, where he was responsible for developing market insights in support of product, go-to-market, and executive stakeholders. Previous to that, John worked as an Analyst covering network, web, and email protection, leading initial research initiatives on then-emerging areas such as advanced threat prevention and DDoS. As an analyst, he has also focused on infrastructure channels, assessing, and advising on the go-to-market strategies of IT vendors, especially from an indirect perspective.

bio: Austin Arensberg is the Vice President of Okta Ventures, the venture capital arm of Okta, a leading identity and access management company. He oversees investments in startups focused on privacy, identity, and security, with Okta Ventures having backed 40 startups since its inception. Austin has over a decade of experience in private equity and corporate development, primarily in Asia, before leading Okta’s strategic investments. He emphasizes the challenges cybersecurity startups face in achieving profitable exits, advocating for strategic planning from Series B onward. Austin also drives initiatives like the Okta Startup Challenge, fostering innovation in identity-driven applications, and the Identity 25 awards, recognizing global leaders in digital identity.

bio: Morey J. Haber is the Chief Security Advisor at BeyondTrust. As the Chief Security Advisor, Morey is the lead identity and technical evangelist at BeyondTrust. He has more than 25 years of IT industry experience and has authored six books published by Apress media. Morey has previously served as BeyondTrust’s Chief Security Officer, Chief Technology Officer, and Vice President of Product Management during his nearly 13-year tenure. In 2020, Morey was elected to the Identity Defined Security Alliance (IDSA) Executive Advisory Board to assist the corporate community with identity security best practices. He originally joined BeyondTrust in 2012 as a part of the eEye Digital Security acquisition where he served as a Product Owner and Solutions Engineer since 2004.

bio: Michael Bargury is a hacker, builder, and a cybersecurity practitioner. He demonstrated the first real-world external attack on an enterprise AI system targeting Microsoft Copilot, and the first end-to-end external hijacking attacks targeting every flagship AI assistant and agent. He revealed novel attack vectors and established countermeasures through security standards in LLMs, agentic AI, cloud, and application security. He is the Co-Founder and CTO of Zenity – securing AI agents everywhere. He is a core contributor to MITRE Atlas, OWASP GenAI, ASI, and LCNC. He regularly delivers research, tools, and talks at top conferences including BlackHat and DEFCON.

bio: Hoyt L. Kesterson II is a Security & Risk Architect with CNC Consulting in Phoenix, Arizona. He has more than 50 years of experience in Information Security and related technologies. For 21 years he chaired the international standards group that created the X.509 digital signature certificate. He was a PCI QSA 2011–2023. He is a Founding Member and Co-Chair of the Information Security Committee in the American Bar Association. He is a testifying expert. He holds CISSP and CISA certifications. He has three articles published in "The SciTech Lawyer—What’s Quantum Computing Got to Do with It?" in the Spring 2022 issue; "Cryptocurrency: A Need for Integrity in the Summer 2023 issue," and "The Synergy of SciTech and the RSA Conference," co-authored with Ruth Hill Bro, in the Fall 2024 issue.

bio: Vivek Vinod Sharma is the Lead AI Security Architect for Microsoft's Internal Enterprise IT Security division. He is a Technical Leader in AI Security and Subject Matter Expert in AI ML Security and Microsoft Cloud Platforms (Azure, M365, D365) Security. He is also empowered to determine which services and features are acceptable for use and how they should be used across Microsoft Enterprise. He is also responsible for creating security guidance that will enable engineering teams to implement services in a secure manner and assessment teams to validate engineering designs and deployments.

bio: Frédéric Rivain is the Chief Technology Officer at Dashlane, a leading cybersecurity company specializing in credential management and digital identity solutions. With over two decades of experience in tech leadership, Frédéric drives innovation in security and privacy. A passionate advocate for user-centric security, he brings a unique perspective on blending convenience and robust protection for both individuals and businesses.

bio: Ofer Maor is a hacker, founder, breaker, builder, and defender. Currently helping defenders to stop cloud breaches with a petabytes-scale Cloud TDIR platform. Before, as CTO & Founder of Seeker Security (acquired by Synopsys), Ofer was the inventor of IAST, the first in-memory runtime code analysis technology, helping builders create secure code. But at my core I'm a Breaker. Ofer spent over a decade white-hacking, publishing the original papers on Blind SQL Injection & SQL Injection Signature Evasion, as well as dozens of other publications, disclosures, and conference talks. He was CTO & Co-Founder of Hacktics, a premium pentesting/red teaming shop (acquired by EY), previously a founding employee at Imperva. He is currently RSAC Program Committee, former OWASP Board Member and more.

bio: Yaw Etse is the Vice President of Data Engineering at Capital One, where he leads our Data Sharing and Privacy engineering teams in Enterprise Data focusing on security, scalability, and operational efficiency. His role at Capital One involves driving innovative solutions and helping the company stay ahead in the competitive financial sector, especially through his involvement in projects on synthetic data and differential privacy. Yaw is actively collaborating with their MLX and academic engagement partners with Harvard on OpenDPand MIT on the Future of Data, to leverage research and advancements in secure data processing and privacy enhancing technologies here at Capital One. Prior to Yaw's tenure at Capital One, Yaw was the VP of Engineering at Invitae.

bio: Dan Stocker is a 30-year veteran of the leading edge of technology, security, and risk management. Specializing in AI, privacy, cloud (including Zero Trust), risk, and governance. Available for consultations and advisory work (at all lifecycle stages) and speaking engagements. Currently focused on product security and AI security uplift strategy, covering advisory, threat modeling, and red teaming. Ancillary roles supporting industry efforts with MITRE and Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) and for AI-related evolutions in other areas (PCI and AIUC-1). Thought leadership focusing on the novel technical, organizational, process, and transformational challenges AI systems pose for security.

bio: John Fokker is Vice President Threat Intelligences Strategy at Trellix, where he and his team drive a cross-functional mission to detect, understand, and disrupt cyber adversaries—delivering intelligence-led outcomes for customers, products, and global partners. Prior to joining Trellix, he served with the Dutch National High-Tech Crime Unit (NHTCU), the Dutch National Police unit dedicated to investigating advanced forms of cybercrime. Over the course of his career, he has supervised numerous large-scale cybercrime investigations and takedowns. John is also a Co-Founder of the NoMoreRansom Project and a Member of the Europol EC3 advisory group on Internet Security.

bio: Ruth Bro has focused her legal career on advising businesses on privacy/info, management strategy, cybersecurity, global compliance, e-workplace, and e-business, speaking over 200 times and publishing 90+ works on these issues, chapters in "ABA Cybersecurity Handbook and Artificial Intelligence: Legal Issues, Policy, and Practical Strategies." A longstanding American Bar Ass’n leader, she is Special Advisor/past Co-Chair of the Cybersecurity Legal Task Force, Member of the Task Force on Law and AI, and past Section Chair and E-Privacy Law Committee Founder/Chair in the SciTech Section. She has served on many ABA-wide entities (Chair, Technology & Info. Systems). Now a consultant after 15 years with two law firms, she earned her BA from Northwestern and JD from the University of Chicago.

bio: Jamie Simmons is a Vice President in US Card’s Fraud and Disputes Strategy team. Jamie leads the internal and external investigative analysts teams, Fraud and KYC Risk Management and our Strategic partnerships and collaboration with law enforcement, merchants, Visa/MC and other key stakeholders in the payment ecosystem. The teams are responsible for identifying and mitigating new and emerging risks, trends and providing actionable intelligence, insights and innovations. Jamie currently serves on the following Industry Boards: Board of advisors for the International Association of Financial Crimes Investigators, Identity Theft Assistance Center, (Observer) Merchant Risk Council Global Board.

bio: Heather Flanagan is the Principal at Spherical Cow Consulting, helping organizations navigate the fast-moving world of digital identity and internet standards. With 15+ years of experience translating complex technical concepts into clear, actionable strategy, she is known for bridging communities and guiding collaborative work. Heather co-chairs the W3C Federated Identity and Exploration Interest Groups, the IETF Secure Patterns for Internet Credentials (SPICE) working group, and HotRFC. Her past roles include leadership positions with the OpenID Foundation, IDPro, the IETF/IRTF, and REFEDS. Named to the 2025 Okta Identity 25 as a top thought leader in digital identity, Heather is a frequent speaker and writer on standards, governance, and the friction of identity implementation.

bio: Mike Ruth is a Senior Staff Security Engineer, SpeakerOps Lead for Cloud Village, and has been publicly speaking about security for close to a decade, including at conferences such as Defcon, Kubecon, and BSidesSF. Previously the technical lead for infrastructure security at companies such as Rippling, Brex, and Cruise, Mike has over 15 years of experience laying the foundation of security programs in cloud, platform, and software supply chain security.

bio: Stephanie Franklin-Thomas is the Vice President and Chief Information Security Officer at Medtronic, overseeing global strategies to protect the company’s operations. With 28 years of experience, she has led security initiatives at Fortune 500 companies like ABM Industries and Motiva Enterprises. She holds an NACD director certification and serves on the boards of St. Luke’s Hospital and The National Cryptologic Foundation. A frequent speaker on cybersecurity and Diversity & Inclusion (D&I), Stephanie is also a Certified Information Systems Auditor and a lifetime member of the National Black MBA Association. She earned her Bachelor's and MBA. from Our Lady of the Lake University and a PhD in Organizational Development and Leadership from Northcentral University.
globalBio: Stephanie Franklin-Thomas is the Vice President and Chief Information Security Officer at Medtronic, overseeing global strategies to protect the company’s operations. With 28 years of experience, she has led security initiatives at Fortune 500 companies like ABM Industries and Motiva Enterprises. She holds an NACD director certification and serves on the boards of St. Luke’s Hospital and The National Cryptologic Foundation. A frequent speaker on cybersecurity and Diversity & Inclusion (D&I), Stephanie is also a Certified Information Systems Auditor and a lifetime member of the National Black MBA Association. She earned her Bachelor's and MBA. from Our Lady of the Lake University and a PhD in Organizational Development and Leadership from Northcentral University.

bio: Ibrahim Waziri Jr., PhD, is a Global Insider Risk Lead at Google Cloud’s CISO Risk and Compliance Insider Threat team, where he leads initiatives in insider risk management, incident management, and global cybersecurity regulations. Previously, he was a Principal Security Product Manager at Microsoft, leading Azure cybersecurity engineering, product development, and incident response for US national security. His expertise spans cybersecurity engineering, national security strategy, responsible AI, and GRC. Ibrahim career includes roles at Marymount University as an Adjunct Professor of Cybersecurity, Deloitte, Apogee Research, RSA Security, and the USITC. He serves on nonprofit boards for cybersecurity and education and holds a PhD in Information Security from Purdue University.
globalBio: Ibrahim Waziri Jr., PhD, is a Global Insider Risk Lead at Google Cloud’s CISO Risk and Compliance Insider Threat team, where he leads initiatives in insider risk management, incident management, and global cybersecurity regulations. His expertise spans cybersecurity engineering, national security strategy, responsible AI, and GRC. bio: With over 20 years of experience in Information Technology and Cybersecurity, Mat Everman has developed a diverse skill set across a broad range of technologies. His work history includes everything from IT Help Desk to Information Security Management across an array of industries including education, industrial, financial, healthcare, and non-profit cybersecurity. His expertise gives him a unique perspective on problem solving and a passion for demystifying cybersecurity. Mat’s commitment to cybersecurity advocacy extends to his free time where he provides free cybersecurity training to local communities and as a guest on cybersecurity focused podcasts.

bio: Sitaram Mandalaparti is Senior Manager of Information Security with over two decades of experience in cybersecurity and technology leadership, driving innovation in Information Security and GRC. He specializes in security strategy, GRC program development, AI risk management, and enterprise application security architecture. At Cirrus Logic, he partners with the legal team on enterprise risk management, strategic AI, and third-party risk initiatives. He is passionate about leveraging AI to automate security and GRC, while maintaining a strong focus on strengthening enterprise resilience and elevating security maturity. He holds an MBA, MS in Mechanical Engineering, and top certifications including CISSP, CISA, CISM, CRISC, and CDPSE.

bio: Roger A. Grimes, CISO Advisor for KnowBe4, Inc., is a 38-year computer security consultant, instructor, holder of dozens of computer certifications, and author of 16 books and over 1,600 magazine articles on computer security. He has spoken at many of the world's biggest computer security conferences, been in Newsweek magazine, appeared on television, been interviewed for NPR's All Things Considered, the Wall Street Journal, and been a guest on dozens of radio shows and podcasts. He has worked at some of the world's largest computer security companies, including Foundstone, McAfee, and Microsoft. He has consulted for hundreds of companies, from the largest to the smallest, around the world. He was the weekly security columnist for InfoWorld/CSOOnline from 2005 to 2019.

bio: Jeremy Schumacher is the Founder of Rivertown Technology Group.  A seasoned technology executive with over 25 years of experience leading cybersecurity, IT strategy, and compliance initiatives for high-growth and private-equity-backed companies. He is known for bridging the gap between business vision and technical execution, providing hands-on executive leadership that drives measurable results in operational efficiency, compliance, and enterprise value.

bio: Melinda Marks leads Omdia’s insights and advisory analyst team focused on cybersecurity. Melinda covers technologies that help organizations scale safely while innovating with new technologies, including cloud services and AI. She has more than 20 years of experience in technology marketing and strategy, focusing on product value and revenue growth. She has held leadership roles at Soluble (acquired by Lacework), Armorblox, Styra, StackRox (acquired by Red Hat), Tenable, Qualys, and VMware, where she built the customer reference program and led product PR. She is a Synopsys Outreach Foundation board member and has a Bachelor’s degree in English from UC Berkeley.

bio: Stephen Giguere started his cybersecurity journey by getting kicked out of high school computing class for escalating privileges on the school Linux system and changing all the passwords to “peaches”. Since then, Stephen's come a long way. With a career spanning aerospace, telecoms, and automotive, Stephen has worked across application security, Kubernetes, and cloud security, and co-authored the O’Reilly book on CNAPP. Today, as Principal AI Security Advocate at Lakera, Stephen focuses on educating teams, experimenting in the open, and helping the industry navigate the real risks of AI-powered applications.

Today, as Principal AI Security Advocate at Lakera, Stephen focuses on educating teams, experimenting in the open, and helping the industry navigate the real risks of AI-powered applications.

bio: Dr. Leila Nova (Taghizadeh) is the Global Head of Cyber Risk, CISO Ibero Latam of international insurance, and Asset Management Leader at Allianz Group. Leila is a results-driven, multilingual, and globally aware business and technology leader, passionate about making the world a better place. With prior experience as a Senior Executive at Swift and Euroclear, she has a strong understanding of the challenges faced by organizations in balancing cyber risk and compliance. In addition to her PhD in Physics and dedication to teaching and research, Leila brings an extensive background in cybersecurity and advocacy for the sustainable use of AI for the greater good, including the application of modern solutions to save the environment and species.

bio: Tomer Agayev is a Staff Security Researcher at Cato Networks and Member of Cato CTRL. Tomer is an expert in malware analysis, advanced threat research, and incident response, contributing to the Cato MDR service. His track record includes conducting in-depth security investigations and making significant contributions to discovering new malware strains in the wild. Prior to joining Cato in 2021, Tomer led the threat research team at Trusteer (acquired by IBM), which mainly focused on advanced threat research, threat hunting, and incident response. Tomer has more than a decade of experience in the field of cybersecurity.
globalBio: Tomer Agayev is a Staff Security Researcher at Cato Networks and Member of Cato CTRL. Tomer is an expert in malware analysis, advanced threat research, and incident response, contributing to the Cato MDR service. His track record includes conducting in-depth security investigations and making significant contributions to discovering new malware strains in the wild. Prior to joining Cato in 2021, Tomer led the threat research team at Trusteer (acquired by IBM), which mainly focused on advanced threat research, threat hunting, and incident response. Tomer has more than a decade of experience in the field of cybersecurity.

bio: Céline Guillou advises clients on a wide range of privacy, security, and AI matters. She provides strategic guidance to companies on complex data governance and compliance, risk management, and evolving regulatory challenges. Céline’s in-depth knowledge stems from a unique blend of experience in both government enforcement (CPPA) and as in-house counsel. Her extensive understanding of the tech landscape, regulatory environment and consumer protection and privacy issues, combined with her experience collaborating cross-functionally with internal teams, enables her to proactively identify and navigate potential concerns for clients.

bio: HD Moore is a pioneer of the cybersecurity industry who has dedicated his career to vulnerability research, network discovery, and software development since the 1990s. He is most recognized for creating Metasploit and is a passionate advocate for open source software and vulnerability disclosure. HD serves as the CEO and Founder of runZero, a provider of cutting-edge cyber asset management software and cloud services. HD's professional journey began with exploring telephone networks, developing exploits for the DoD, and hacking into financial institution networks. When he's not working, he enjoys hacking on weird Go projects, building janky electronics, running in circles, and playing single-player RPGs.

bio: Megan Benoit has spent most of the last 20+ years building incident response and vulnerability management programs, architecting and deploying security solutions, shutting down penetration testers, and telling management she’s a security engineer, not a miracle worker. She is currently a Lead Security Engineer for Nebraska Medicine and previously worked for the DoD, as well as the healthcare and retail industries. When she’s not spending time with her kids, she teaches yoga and fitness classes because when she tells people what to do, they don’t argue.

bio: Tinsae (Tin) Erkailo is a Principal Product Manager at Elastic, where he leads the Elastic Workflows, bringing native workflow automation to the Elasticsearch platform. His work focuses on enabling teams to automate work directly where their data lives, combining reliable execution with contextual reasoning. Prior to leading workflow automation, Tin was the product manager for Elastic’s Cloud Security capabilities and earlier worked as a Security Analyst at Elastic and as an Ethical Hacker at MassMutual. Tin studied Computer Science at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and is currently based in Brooklyn, New York.

bio: Anthony Rodriguez is AVP of Application Security Engineering and Threat Management at CVS Health, bringing deep experience in technology and security leadership across healthcare and retail. Prior to CVS Health, he served as Senior Director of Security for Cloud, Applications, and Architecture at Baptist Health South Florida, where he led major security and infrastructure initiatives. He previously held the role of Division Vice President of Security at Hudson’s Bay Company, driving large-scale digital and security transformations. At CVS Health, Anthony leads the development of a high-performing Security and Threat Management organization, overseeing Threat Management, Operational Security Engineering and Application Security Engineering to advance the company’s digital security strategy.

bio: Fred Frey is the Splunk Director of AI Engineering for Security Products, where he drives the development of AI capabilities that strengthen and scale modern security operations. With more than 20 years of experience spanning offensive and defensive cyber missions, he has built and led red teams, threat hunting programs, and threat intelligence initiatives for Fortune 500 and government organizations. Fred is dedicated to pushing the boundaries of practical AI to help defenders detect, hunt, and respond to threats with greater speed and precision.

bio: Rick Grinnell is Founder and Managing Partner of Glasswing Ventures, investing in AI-native security and enterprise infrastructure. An experienced venture capitalist and operator, Rick has invested in dynamic security companies and serves on boards including Allure Security, Black Kite, Cydelphi, Nametag, Realm.Security, Sigma Automate, and Trustle. Notable prior investments that have exited include Digital Guardian (HelpSystems), EqualLogic (Dell), Prelert (Elastic), Resilient Systems (IBM), TrackVia (Primus Capital), and VeloBit (Western Digital). Rick serves on MIT's Educational Council, advises at Harvard Business School's Rock Center and the MIT iHQ, and is a Board Member of MIT Sandbox and the Advanced Cyber Security Center.

bio: John Strand is the Owner of Black Hills Information Security, a firm specializing in Penetration Testing, Active Defense, and Hunt Teaming services. He is also the CTO of Active Countermeasures, a firm dedicated to tracking advanced attackers inside and outside a network. He feels strongly that education is how the world of Information Security will change for the better and spends a considerable amount of time teaching and presenting around the world. John has presented to the FBI, NASA, the NSA, and at various industry conferences. He also Co-Hosts "Security Weekly," the world's largest Information Security podcast, Co-Authored "Offensive Countermeasures: The Art of Active Defense," writes loud rock music, and makes various futile attempts at fly-fishing.

Yaron Levi is the CISO for Dolby Laboratories and a Research Fellow for the Cloud Security Alliance. 
Prior to Dolby, Yaron was the CISO for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City, and deputy CISO for Cerner Corporation. Yaron also serves as an advisor to several VCs and security startups

bio: J.R. Rao is an IBM Fellow and CTO for Security Research, leading 200+ researchers focused on AI security, cybersecurity, cloud security, and cryptography. As Co-Chair of OASIS Open Group's Coalition for Secure AI (CoSAI) Technical Steering Committee and member of its Executive Steering Committee, he drives vendor-neutral AI security standards across 40+ organizations including Google, Microsoft, and OpenAI. His research spans Using AI for security and securing AI, working with commercial and government customers to integrate innovative security technologies into IBM products, and definitive industry standards. Rao has published extensively in premier security conferences and holds numerous US and European patents, focusing on raising security quality while easing deployment complexity.

Rao has published extensively in premier security conferences and holds numerous US and European patents, focusing on raising security quality while easing deployment complexity.

bio: Mike Armistead is a cybersecurity entrepreneur and pioneer with nearly 40 years of experience building and scaling transformative DevOps, consumer, and security companies. As CEO and Co-Founder of Pulse Security AI, he is defining a new category of tools, situational security management, which help security leaders build and maintain security programs that effectively accomplish their mission to protect the enterprise.  Previously, Mike co-founded Fortify Software (acquired by HP), which helped define the application security market, and later co-founded Respond Software (acquired by Mandiant/Google), introducing AI-driven automation to security operations.

bio: Aaron Alva is a technologist and attorney who served at the Federal Trade Commission as a lead technology advisor and Counsel to the Director. Aaron was instrumental in driving the FTC's approach to privacy and security enforcement while advancing consumer protection and competition cases. His track record includes multiple high-profile cases such Facebook ($5bn privacy settlement), Amazon Alexa, GoodRx, BetterHelp, Marriott, GoDaddy, Avast, and more. Aaron recently launched the Alva Strategy Center—a new venture devoted to furthering security and privacy for all and enabling responsible AI innovation. Offline, Aaron can often be found coxing or rowing.

bio: Robert Pisarczyk is the CEO and Co-Founder of Oblivious, a Dublin-based company pioneering Privacy-Enhancing Technologies. Oblivious empowers financial institutions and tech firms to safely accelerate AI adoption and turn compliance into a competitive advantage. Robert holds a PhD in Mathematics from the University of Oxford, supervised by quantum cryptography pioneer Prof. Artur Ekert, with research published in top-tier journals. Previously a researcher at the Centre for Quantum Technologies, Robert currently shapes global standards as a member of the United Nations Task Team on Privacy-Enhancing Technologies and an editor of the UN PET Guide.

bio: Chris Camacho is Co-Founder and Chief Operating Officer of Abstract Security, where he helps build practical, scalable solutions to modern cyber challenges. With more than 25 years of experience leading security programs across global enterprises and high-growth startups, he has held leadership roles at Flashpoint, Bank of America, and the World Bank. A trusted industry voice and natural connector, Chris brings operators, executives, and innovators together to turn real-world security problems into systems that work

bio: Adi Shamir is the Borman Professor of Computer Science at the Weizmann Institute in Israel. Adi specializes in cryptographic schemes and protocols, with special emphasis on cryptanalysis. He co-developed the RSA cryptosystem with Rivest and Adleman; introduced the notion of secret sharing; broke the Merkle-Hellman knapsack-based cryptosystem; developed differential cryptanalysis with Biham; proposed the notion of identity-based cryptography; developed the Fiat-Shamir identification and signature schemes; and showed (with Tromer) how to use new side channel attacks, such as cache attacks and acoustic attacks to break numerous cryptosystems.
globalBio: Adi Shamir is the Borman Professor of Computer Science at the Weizmann Institute in Israel. Adi specializes in cryptographic schemes and protocols, with special emphasis on cryptanalysis. bio: Yoav Leitersdorf, Managing Partner at YL Ventures, has been a successful tech entrepreneur and investor for over 25 years. He founded YL Ventures in 2007 to help seed-stage entrepreneurs transform their ideas into game-changing companies. Today, YL Ventures is fully focused on seeding cybersecurity startups. Under his leadership, YL Ventures has raised over $800M across five funds and expanded into a growing multidisciplinary team of experts supporting promising startups at every milestone with tailored value-add initiatives. Yoav regularly speaks and interviews about the state of the cybersecurity industry and writes articles for major tech publications including TechCrunch, VentureBeat, CSO Online, Forbes, and more. Prior to YL Ventures, Yoav founded, grew, and sold three tech startups.

bio: Dawn Song is a Professor in Computer Science at UC Berkeley and Co-Director of Berkeley Center on Responsible Decentralized Intelligence. Her research interest lies in AI safety, AI security, deep learning, security, and privacy. She is the recipient of numerous awards including the MacArthur Fellowship, Guggenheim Fellowship, and more than ten Test-of-Time Awards and Best Paper Awards. She is an ACM Fellow and IEEE Fellow. She is ranked the most cited scholar in computer security (AMiner Award). Dawn is an elected member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. She is also a serial entrepreneur, named on the Female Founder 100 List by Inc. and Wired25 List of Innovators.
globalBio: Dawn Song is a Professor in Computer Science at UC Berkeley and Co-Director of Berkeley Center on Responsible Decentralized Intelligence. Her research interest lies in AI safety, AI security, deep learning, security, and privacy. She is the recipient of numerous awards including the MacArthur Fellowship, Guggenheim Fellowship, and more than ten Test-of-Time Awards and Best Paper Awards. She is an ACM Fellow and IEEE Fellow. She is ranked the most cited scholar in computer security (AMiner Award). Dawn is an elected member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. She is also a serial entrepreneur, named on the Female Founder 100 List by Inc. and Wired25 List of Innovators.

bio: Dave is the Head of Global Technology Investment Banking for Morgan Stanley and has over 25 years of investment banking experience.  In cybersecurity, Dave has had the privilege of advising on key transactions including the Direct Listings for Palantir and IPOs for Avast, McAfee, Fireeye, Fortinet, Palo Alto Networks, SentinelOne, Zscaler and many others. He has also advised on M&A transactions such as CyberArk’s $1.5bn acquisition of Venafi, the $28bn sale of Splunk to Cisco, Thales’ $3.6bn acquisition of Imperva from Thoma Bravo, $7.7bn sale of McAfee to Intel, the $1bn acquisition of Mandiant by FireEye, and more. On the private financing side, Dave served as lead placement agent on ForeScout's $76mm, Arctic Wolf’s $401mm and Netskope’s $401mm financing round.

bio: Ira Winkler, CISSP, is CISO of CYE Security and Director of the Human Security Engineering Consortium. He authored the books, "You Can Stop Stupid" and "Security Awareness for Dummies," and is considered one of the world’s most influential security professionals. Ira was named “The Awareness Crusader” by CSO Magazine in receiving their CSO COMPASS Award. Most recently, he was named 2021 Top Cybersecurity Leader by Security Magazine. He has designed, implemented, and supported security awareness programs at organizations in all industries around the world. Ira began his career at the National Security Agency, where he served as an Intelligence and Computer Systems Analyst. He has since served in other positions supporting the cybersecurity programs in organizations of all sizes.

bio: Terry Luan is a Masters of Engineering student at the University of Toronto. As one of the Village Leads for the Physical Security Village, he helps with much of the Village logistics, as well as volunteer and external management. His main areas of interest are in security (both physical and virtual), lockpicking, and he loves teaching people about various security exploits.

bio: Michael Klieman is Entrust’s Global Vice President of Product Management, responsible for Entrust’s Data Security segment. Michael brings more than 30 years of experience in product and design leadership, business development, and general management in cybersecurity, fintech, and healthcare technology. Prior to Entrust, Michael led product management for OneSpan, Sophos, MobileIron/Ivanti, and Symantec/Digicert. His experience includes enabling the shift from on-premises to SaaS based applications for security solutions including digital signature, unified endpoint management, mobile security, passwordless authentication, SSL/TLS, code signing, vulnerability and malware detection, endpoint protection, and PKI.

bio: Carsten Meywirth has been the Head of the Cybercrime Department of the Bundeskriminalamt (German Federal Criminal Police Office) since it was founded in April 2020. He joined Bundeskriminalamt in 1987, after his police training with the Lower Saxony police force. Over more than thirty years of service, Carsten has held various managerial positions in the central services and organized and general crime departments, including managing various projects in the IT department. In 2008, he became the Head of Staff for the IT director. Further, he led the cybercrime group within the organized and serious crime department for three years and, from 2016, the central logistics tasks group in the central administration department.

bio: A graduate of the US Air Force Academy, Paul Suarez served his entire 27-year Air Force career in the fields of cybersecurity and information technology. After his military retirement he worked in business development in the Washington, DC area for Netwitness, RSA Security and Avaya then as security engineering director for Walmart prior to becoming their CISO for Walmart International.  He joined Casey’s, the country’s 3rd largest convenience store chain, in 2021 as their very first CISO.

bio: Saurabh Shintre is the Founder and CEO of Realm Labs and previously led the AI security research at Splunk and Symantec. He has been at the forefront of AI security research for nearly a decade with multiple publications and patents and regularly features on public forums on issues regarding security and AI. Saurabh holds a PhD from Carnegie Mellon.

bio: Abhinav Verma is a Staff Offensive Security Engineer at Intuit with over 12 years of experience in offensive security, AI security, and red teaming. He specializes in AI threat modeling, GenAI security, penetration testing, and secure architecture. He leads AI security testing, architecture reviews, and vulnerability management at Intuit. Previously, he drove cloud security automation and built secure coding programs for thousands of developers. He holds OSEP, OSCP, GWAPT, OSWP, and CEH certifications. Outside of work, Abhinav is a passionate gamer and a trained chef.

bio: Nicole Nichols is a Distinguished Engineer in Machine Learning Security at Palo Alto Networks and has contributed to both academic and industrial advancements in adversarial machine learning and security. She leads research and development solutions for Cortex Foundational AI Research (FAIR). She has published at ACM, IEEE, and CVPR workshops, was co-chair of ICML ML4Cyber workshop, and is an advisor to the AI Security Forum. She was an invited keynote speaker for ACM-AiSec 2025. She is a Polymath Fellow in Artificial Intelligence for the Global Fellowship Initiative at the Geneva Centre for Security Policy. She has a PhD in Electrical Engineering from the University of Washington.

She has a PhD in Electrical Engineering from the University of Washington.

bio: Robin Bender Ginn is the Executive Director of the OpenJS Foundation. Hosted by the Linux Foundation, OpenJS is the neutral home to grow and sustain the JavaScript and web ecosystem with 30 projects including Node.js, deck.gl, Electron, Express, Jest, jQuery, and webpack. Previously, Robin was at the forefront of Microsoft’s shift to openness where she led major initiatives to advance open source technologies, community development, and open standards.

bio: Ray Espinoza is Vice President of Information Security at Elite Technology. With over 18 years of both tactical and security leadership experience, Ray has a proven track record of successfully building effective security programs for top companies that include eBay, Cisco, Amazon and Cobalt.io. Prior to joining Elite, Ray served as VP and CISO at Inspectiv where he was responsible for developing and executing Inspectiv's security and cloud strategies. Outside of work, Ray is the head strength and conditioning coach and an assistant football coach at Camas High School.

bio: Konstantinos Karagiannis has been helping companies with quantum computing threats and opportunities since 2012. He is the Senior Director of Quantum Computing Services at Protiviti, helping customers find innovative use cases for this exciting new technology. Before starting up this new division, Konstantinos has worked on securing everything from Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) to blockchain and smart contracts, and has spoken at dozens of technical conferences worldwide, including RSAC, DEF CON, Black Hat Europe, and ISF World Security Congress. Konstantinos is also the host of the podcast series “The Post-Quantum World.”

bio: Maor Dahan is a Senior Security Researcher at Akamai with more than a decade of experience in the cybersecurity industry. He specializes in operating system internals, vulnerability research, and malware analysis. Maor also has extensive experience designing and developing advanced detection and prevention mechanisms for innovative security products such as EDR, EPP, and virtualization-based security.

bio: Mattia Epifani earned his degree in Computer Science at Genoa University and attended the “Computer Forensics and Digital Investigations” specialization course at Milan University. He has also obtained several certifications in digital forensics and ethical hacking, including GNFA, GSAF, GREM, GCFA, GMOB, GCWN, GCFE, GOSI, GIME, GBFA, and CIFI. He is the Global Digital Forensics Senior Advisor at BIT4LAW and the CEO of the company he founded, Reality Net System Solutions, where he operates in cybersecurity and digital investigations for legal proceedings and private customers. Mattia is a Certified Instructor at SANS Institute for FOR500 and FOR585 and the Author of "Learning iOS Forensics" published by PacktPub. Find him on LinkedIn and Zena Forensics (blog).

bio: Dr. Shawn P. Murray is the Immediate Past President for ISSA International. He was previously assigned to the United States Missile Defense Agency as a Senior Program Manager. His previous assignments include work with the US Army Cyber Command in Europe, US Air Force, and with Commercial Industry in various roles in information assurance and cybersecurity. He has traveled the globe performing physical and cybersecurity assessments on critical national defense and coalition programs and has prepared reports for the House Armed Services Committee and has testified on cybersecurity and privacy issues for leaders in Congress.

bio: Joe Levy is the CEO of Sophos, a global leader in cybersecurity defending over 600,000 organizations worldwide. A 30-year industry veteran, Joe blends hands-on technical expertise with a strategic vision to redefine how organizations of all sizes defend against modern cyber threats. Since becoming CEO in 2024, he has grown Sophos into one of the largest dedicated MDR providers in the world. A recognized subject matter expert on agentic AI and cyber risk, Joe is a member of the Aspen US Cybersecurity Group and several advisory councils for leading investment and security organizations. Previously, he served as CTO at Sophos, Solera Networks, Blue Coat Systems, and SonicWALL. Joe earned his BA from Queens College, City University of New York.

bio: Jess Burn is a Principal Analyst at Forrester serving security and risk professionals. She contributes to Forrester’s research on the role of the CISO with a focus on cybersecurity talent management. She also covers incident response and email and collaboration security. Jess spent the last eight years as a Principal Advisor on Forrester’s Security & Risk Council. In this role, she was a trusted partner to a network of CISOs and security and risk leaders making critical decisions in the areas of risk management, data privacy and protection, cybersecurity operations, and identity and access management. Prior to her role as an advisor, Jess led a Forrester Consulting practice focused on helping tech providers with their business and go-to-market.

bio: Erez Harush is the AI Research Lead at Wiz. He leads the company's AI research team, focusing on autonomous agents for threat investigation, security operations automation, and security posture management. Previously, Erez spent seven years at Demisto (acquired by Palo Alto Networks) as Senior Principal Data Scientist, where he built machine learning systems for incident response. He served six years in the Israel Defense Forces' elite Unit 8200 intelligence corps. Erez completed his BSc in Computer Science and Physics at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem as a member of the Talpiot program, and his MSc in Computer Science at IDC Herzliya.

Erez completed his BSc in Computer Science and Physics at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem as a member of the Talpiot program, and his MSc in Computer Science at IDC Herzliya.

bio: Sid Trivedi is a Partner at Foundation Capital, where he leads early-stage investments in cybersecurity and IT. His investments include Stacklet, AirMDR, Prime Security, Pulse Security, Aegis AI, Permiso, DevZero, Nimble Security, Levo, Phenom, Attivo Networks (acq. SentinelOne), CloudKnox (acq. Microsoft), Respond Software (acq. Mandiant), and MistNet (acq. LogRhythm). Sid was previously an Investor at Omidyar Technology Ventures and Symphony Technology Group. He is Co-founder of CyberSeed, a community of over 1,700 cybersecurity founders and Co-host of the "Inside the Network podcast," which shares how category-defining cyber startups are built. Sid serves on the advisory boards of Entrepreneurship at Cornell, the California Israel Chamber of Commerce, and Cornell Venture Capital.

bio: Marcus H. Sachs is the Senior VP & Chief Engineer for the Center for Internet Security (CIS). He advises CIS leadership on engineering practices and processes; he also participates in the design, development, and review of CIS products and services. Marcus represents CIS in a variety of public forums and activities and serves as an internationally recognized thought leader and advocate for CIS best practices, solutions, and offerings. Marcus retired from the US Army in January 2002 after serving a distinguished 20-year career as a Corps of Engineers and Systems Automation officer. After his military retirement, he was appointed by President George W. Bush to serve in the White House Office of Cyberspace Security. In May 2003, he joined the DHS as its first Cyber Program Director.

bio: Mary Carmichael, ICD.D, CPA, CRISC, CISM, CISA, is Managing Director of Risk Advisory at Momentum Technology with over 15 years’ experience in enterprise and technology risk management across multiple sectors. A Catalyst Fellow at Toronto Metropolitan University, she researches AI supply chain vulnerabilities. She serves on ISACA’s Global CRISC Committee and Emerging Trends Working Group, advising on AI’s impact to governance, risk, and compliance functions. A published author, global speaker, and Immediate Past President of ISACA Vancouver Chapter, Mary is also a designated Board Director, has conducted governance reviews for organizations and technology initiatives. She sits on the advisory board for SiberX for the design and delivery of its cyber crisis simulation exercises.

bio: Camille Stewart Gloster is a strategist, advisor, and executive recognized for leadership across technology, cybersecurity, AI, and national security. She leads CAS Strategies, a strategy firm that helps organizations turn converging AI, cybersecurity, and digital governance risks into durable advantage. Camille previously served as the inaugural Deputy National Cyber Director for Technology & Ecosystem Security at the White House, leading national efforts on emerging tech, supply chain security, data protection, and the cyber workforce. She joined ONCD from Google, where she served as Global Head of Product Security Strategy, and has held senior roles at DHS, Deloitte, and leading cybersecurity companies guiding enterprise security, product security, trust and safety, and AI resilience.

bio: Jason Healey is a Senior Research Scholar at Columbia University SIPA. Prior, at the Atlantic Council he created the global “Cyber 9/12” student cyber-policy competition. He has twice worked cyber issues in the White House, including as a Founding Member of the Office of the National Cyber Director. He edited the first history book of conflict in cyberspace, "A Fierce Domain: Cyber Conflict," 1986 to 2012 and helped create the world’s first cyber command in 1998, pioneering the new field of cyber threat intelligence. He was vice chair of the FS-ISAC and created Goldman Sachs’ first cyber response team. He is a review board member of the DEF CON and Black Hat security conferences and a top-rated speaker for the RSAC Conference and won the inaugural best-of-briefings award at Black Hat.
companyName: Columbia University School of Intl and Public Affairs

bio: Frank Kim is a Fellow at the SANS Institute where he leads the cloud security and CISO leadership curricula to help shape and develop the next generation of security leaders. Previously, he served as the organization's CISO where he led the information risk function for the most trusted source of cybersecurity training and certification in the world. He was also the CISO-in-Residence at YL Ventures where he supported cybersecurity entrepreneurs with ideation and market research, conducted due diligence for potential investments, and engaged in go-to-market activities of the firm's portfolio companies. Frank serves as an advisor to numerous security startups and authors and teaches courses on CISO leadership, strategic planning, DevSecOps, and cloud security.

bio: Andrea Little Limbago is a computational social scientist specializing in the intersection of geopolitics, geoeconomics, and evolving technologies. As the Senior Vice President, Applied AI at Interos, Andrea leads the company’s research and computational modeling regarding global supply chain risk. She is also a Senior Fellow at the National Security Institute at George Mason and a Member of the Cyber Guild’s Luminary Network. Andrea previously taught in academia, was a Technical Lead at the Department of Defense, and was Chief Social Scientist at Endgame and Virtru. She earned a PhD in Political Science from the University of Colorado at Boulder and a BA from Bowdoin College.

bio: Helen Patton is a strategic Cybersecurity Advisor at Cisco. She was the CISO at The Ohio State University and in multiple security roles at JPMorgan Chase. Helen actively encourages cybersecurity collaboration across and within industries, to enable better Information Security and privacy practices. She believes in improving diversity and inclusion in the cyber workforce, and mentors people interested in pursuing careers in security, privacy, and risk management. She advocates for more naps and is anti-bagpipes. Helen has a Master’s Degree in Public Policy. She serves on various advisory boards and community groups and is a founder of the Cybersecurity Canon. Helen is a Blogger and Author of “Navigating the Cybersecurity Career Path."

bio: Nicholas Dhaeyer is a Threat Hunter and Senior OT Analyst at NVISO, specializing in threat hunting, incident response, and Industrial Control System (ICS)/Operational Technology (OT) Security. In his role at the NVISO Security Operations Center (SOC), Nicholas has addressed numerous security incidents for Managed Detection and Response (MDR) clients. Additionally, he has established the OT SOC within NVISO alongside his colleague.

bio: Senan Moloney is the Chief Technology Officer for Callsign, an industry leading provider of identity trust and security solutions. Prior to that he served as the Global Head of Cybercrime for Barclays and the lead for the bank’s Cyber Fraud Fusion Centre, a unit focused on intelligence-driven defense against fraud and financial crime. Prior to joining Barclays, Senan worked as a Senior Cybercrime Specialist in the European Cybercrime Centre at Europol assisting international law enforcement investigations against organized cybercriminal groups. Senan is an established industry speaker, advisor and board member supporting organizations with transformation of fraud and financial crime prevention strategies and he is the co-founder of the ‘Fraud Kill Chain’.

Senan is an established industry speaker, advisor and board member supporting organizations with transformation of fraud and financial crime prevention strategies and he is the co-founder of the ‘Fraud Kill Chain’.

bio: Katherine McDaniel is the Director of the Cyber Legal team at T-Mobile, where she advises on cybersecurity law, privacy, and compliance, helping the company align legal strategy with business and security objectives. She provides guidance on emerging products and services, ensuring compliance with evolving cyber laws, regulations, and best practices. Katherine collaborates closely with cybersecurity, fraud, compliance, and investigations teams to manage legal risk and support enterprise resilience. In addition to her work at T-Mobile, she teaches cybersecurity law and leadership at Seattle University School of Law and the Albers School of Business & Economics. Katherine began her career in private practice in New York and is a graduate of Yale Law School and the University of Washington.

bio: Dan Segev is an Architect on the Wiz CTO Team, specializing in Data & AI security. His career bridges cybersecurity and AI, having led R&D as a former Group Leader in Unit 81 and held technical roles at the intersection of AI and security across startups. Dan is a Talpiot graduate and holds an MBA from Stanford, an MSc in Computer Science from Weizmann Institute, and a BSc in Physics and Computer Science from The Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

bio: For over 25 years, Stephen Ward has been immersed in cybersecurity, honing expertise across leadership roles as an investor at Insight Partners where he invested in companies like Wiz and Abnormal Security. Prior to that, he was the CISO of The Home Depot and TIAA, and in Security Operations at JPMorgan Chase. His journey began in the US Coast Guard and US Secret Service, instilling discipline and a commitment to safeguarding others. Most recently, he co-founded Brightmind Partners, an early-stage venture capital firm leading investments in cybersecurity. Over the past four years, he's supported and invested in some of the industry's fastest-growing companies. Beyond professional endeavors, he is a devoted autism advocate, inspired every day by his amazing son.

bio: Olivier Bilodeau is a Principal Cybersecurity Researcher at Flare. With more than 12 years of cybersecurity experience, Olivier runs honeypots, investigates infostealer infections, and maintains RDP interception technology. He authored several important AV industry reports like "Dissecting Linux/Moose," "Operation Windigo" (about the Ebury malware), and "Ego-Market: When Greed for Fame Benefits Large-Scale Botnets." Passionate communicator, Olivier has spoken at several conferences like RSAC Conference (US), BlackHat (USA/Europe), DefCon, 44CON, Botconf, SecTor, Derbycon, AtlSecCon, and more. Invested in his community, he co-organizes MontréHack—a monthly workshop focused on applied Information Security. He is NorthSec’s Vice-President and runs its Hacker Jeopardy.
